The Prime Minister said that a desire had been expressed that there shouldl be a debate in the following week in the Houseof Commons on the operations in Crete. The debate must takeplace, although his own view was that it did not increase the prestige of the House that a debate should take place on what wasno more than an isolated operation in the middle of a big campaign.As regards procedure he proposed, in reply to a question, toindicate that no Government speech would be made at the openingof the debate, which would be held' in public; but that a speechwould be made by a Government spokesman at the close of theproceedings if the course of the debate made this necessary.[22597]The War Cabinet approved generally the course proposed.b2 ^previous reference:W.M. To do so would be bad for morale, and would make difficulties in regard to fire-fighting. Several members of the War Cabinet feared lest in the debate on Civil Defence in the House of Commons in the following week, Members of Parliament might unwittingly make statements which would impart information to the enemy. The HomeSecretary and Minister of Home Security undertook to send thePrime Minister a list of such points.The Prime Minister said that, at the beginning of the Debate,he would move the House into Secret Session for a short period,and detail to the House certain matters which, in the public interest,must not be referred to in open discussion.The War Cabinet approved this suggestion.The Home Secretary and Minister of Home Security said thatcertain points in regard to Civil Defence organisations were likelyto be raised in the Debate. Thus (1) The Select Committee on National Expenditure, in their14th Report, had recommended that further considera-tion should be given to the concentration of all civil defence functions in a single Ministry. Since12 Departments of State were concerned in civil defence matters, this was clearly impracticable.(2) Another proposal, to which some publicity had been given,was that the control of Local Authorities over civil defence matters should be taken from them and vested in the Regional Commissioners. This would involvecutting in half those Local Authority organisations which had both Civil Defence and peace-time functions.It would also give rise to grave shortage of adminis-trative personnel. On the whole, the Local authorities had done Civil Defence work well, and arrangements could be made to provide stiffening or special assistancewhere necessary.The Prime Minister, while he was in general agreement withthe line which the Home Secretary proposed to take in debate,thought that it would be better not to close the door to possiblechanges in organisation in the future. The line taken might be toindicate that the changes proposed would involve violent readjust-ments of the existing machine, and it seemed very doubtful whatbenefit would be derived from them; but that the Government were at all times prepared to consider such readjustments in organisation as experience might suggest.The War Cabinet Agreed that the Home Secretary and Minister of home security should deal with the matter on these lines.
